title: Why?
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]
3D Realms website - Games

DISCONTINUED GAME INFORMATION

All the following games have been discontinued AND ARE NO LONGER AVAILABLE. It is not legal for you to email/upload/download/trade/distribute these titles under any condition. We do, however, retain the copyright on all of these games: Alien Carnage / Halloween Harry, Kroz, Dark Ages, Arctic Adventure, Monuments of Mars, & Pharaoh's Tomb.
[hr][/quote]

Why do companies do this? Why do they make games, then quit making those games, and then leave them in limbo?

I mean, why not make it freeware? Hell, if you aren't selling it and you have no intention to, then why, WHY?, would you not allow people to have it?

I mean, if there's not a profit to be made... Can't they just let go?


Bio Menace took years to become freeware, and I don't even know if Bio2 and Bio3 ever became freeware! Btu what was the point? They just quit selling it and then left it to die.


It's almost like Commander Keen 6. The company owns the rights to it, but they just leave it on the shelf for no reason.

Halloween Harry, as near as I can remember, was an excellent games. I remember playing it a few years ago... But now it's illegal to download it under any circumstances? What kind of shit is that?


Does anyone think there is any logic to doing this?

title: Re: Why?
content:
There never were any sequels to Bio Menace.
Part 2 and 3 are actually episodes, just like episodes 2 and 3 of Duke Nukem (the original) aren't real sequels, since Duke Nukem 2 was that.
So... all of them were made freeware.

As for that quote, it's nonsense to say it's not legal to trade those games.
If I bought Alien Carnage and want to trade it with someone, or sell it, it's perfectly legal for me to do so.
I bought the rights to the game, so I'm allowed to do that.
The same goes for uploading it and letting someone else download it, as long as I delete it from my computer after that, including any backups.
If I want to give someone my copy for free, I can do that.
It's obvious what 3DR means, but "under any condition" is simply untrue.

I agree about the freeware suggestion.
I suspect some more games will become freeware eventually though.Retodon8
Sheep happens! [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Keen/Graphics/K1_nme_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: Re: Why?
content: It's this kind of iDiocy that makes me disregard a lot of the so-called laws about the entertainment industries. Good thing there are an abundance of abandonware sites to counteract such nonsense. Still, too bad there are so many people who'll probably miss out on playing these games.

title: Re: Why?
content: [img]http://www.psychoholiday.com/uploader/files/58/avastmort.gif[/img][center]<font color="MAROON">TOUGH GUYS DON'T FOLLOW FADS</font>[/center]

title: Re: Why?
content:
There is actually a perfectly good reason why companies do this, it i based apon profit-loss-rescource conflict [Yeah, I've been looking at my brother's management books]

The reasoning is siple enough; while the games are not selling enough copies to make it profitable to continue producing them for sale; the company still wants to retain the fullcopyright on these games in the event that either their popularity increases to the point where sale is a possibility, or the copyrights can be sold to a third party for a profit. This might happen if say a GBC version of said game were to be released. [But this didn't happen with keen, which is by inference both more popular and valuable than above discontinued games.]

Nowadays this is a real possibility, games companies the world over are looking for old games to remake.

A proud member of the Spleen Extinction society

[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v410/Gannalev/rcwn.png[/img]

"No one should be here."
-Levellord

title: Re: Why?
content:
Take for example...


ART!


I make a print. It becomes mildly popular, on some posters etc. People don't want to buy it anymore and production stops.

Then some asshole thinks that just because it "isn't being printed anymore it should be free" decides to start making prints of my image again. I don't like it because it is my image.

It's MY property. It's MY art. I own it. If I don't want it to be made anymore and sold then so be it. I do not want people to be distributing it though.

OH MY GOD GAL! THAT'S SO SELFISH!

Is it? You are being just as selfish saying "Give me your work for free!" I put a lot of time and effort into the print. You are mad because you aren't getting your selfish desires and insist on getting what you want for free.

That's the reasoning. Yes there is logic. I know you will refuse to understand, but that's that.-----------------------
[url=http://Galaxie.Spatang.com][img]http://i34.photobucket.com/albums/d134/Galaxieretter/New-blegd-smeeg-banner-60.png[/img][/url]

title: Re: Why?
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]It's MY property. It's MY art. I own it. If I don't want it to be made anymore and sold then so be it. I do not want people to be distributing it though.[hr][/quote]
Of course, that raises the question of whether it's your decision to make. Okay, so you made it. That's great, but why should you get unlimited control over what everyone else does with it? If you want complete control, then put it in a box. Quick, before anyone sees it!

Not that I want to get embroiled in a copyright discussion.________________
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v462/lemur821/toughyorp.png[/img]

Gal, I'm not saying they shouldn't have the ability. But (A) don't try to use the artist excuse. These companies only fronted the cash for these games --they don't have the connection to these games that the actual artists do.

Also, this isn't like pirating Eminem songs. We aren't demanding a free copy just because we want one. We want a shot at getting a copy. We can't get our hands, legally, on even a freaking Demo because of their assinine rules.


LL, I know, but making a GBA game and releasing something as Freeware is entirely different. I can release a game as Freeware and still make a GBA collection of it. (Say you make a Duke Nukem I & II collection of it after they make it Freeware.)

Hell, thje GBA collection would create profits for the company (And I'd buy it), but the DOS is just going to rot there. They know it. I know it. So why not just give the DOS version away?

title: Re: ...
content:
Well basically Glo; they're selfish. Once you release a game as freeware, you can't go back. Wheras discontinuing you can release it as freeware or reproduce whenever you want.

Managers don't like doing final things like releasing a game; its like losing a piece of property, or making sensible gun control laws.A proud member of the Spleen Extinction society

title: Re: ...
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]
LevelLord:

Well basically Glo; they're selfish. Once you release a game as freeware, you can't go back. Wheras discontinuing you can release it as freeware or reproduce whenever you want.

Managers don't like doing final things like releasing a game; its like losing a piece of property, or making sensible gun control laws.

[hr][/quote]

The later is an oxymoron; however, I just don't see the need.


They aren't thinking economically here:

A. In order to sell a product, there needs to be two things: Supply and demand.
B. They have the supply. Currently the demand is me and about 1,000 (approx) other oldie gamers. 1,000 (Or even 20,000) games isn't enough to start re-making these labels.
C. Therefore there is no profit in making these games. You can't have profit when there isn't any (notable) demand.


I mean, is it even slightly forseable that there will ever be a "retro-game renesciance" that could ever come close to building a demand?


That's my point. There is never going to be a demand, and therefore no profit. So if there's no profit, there's no reason to worry about lawbreakers, etc. If they release it as freeware, it still leaves them open to make other games (Like a huge collection of Apogee games on GBA or something, or completely new ones like they do with Duke Nukem.)~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...

title: Re: ...
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]mmmmmmmmm remotely possible like 1 on 10000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000 ?
indeed this has nothing to do with logic but how stupid you are[hr][/quote]

Well, that was nice.
Also, it has everything to do with logic.

No matter how small the possibility, it is there.
If I told you you had a 1 in 10000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000 chance to win a million dollars, that you are already subscribed, and that it doesn't cost you anything, would you leave it at that, or would you cancel the subscription?
If you go for the second option, you are the one that's stupid, it doesn't get any more logical than that.
Of course in this case with the freeware games I suppose cancelling the deal would make people happy at least; after all there is a small group of old game lovers who'd like to see things turn freeware, but it's a very small group, so there's not much to gain.
Although I like 3DR, it's still a company, and companies prefer earning money over being nice.Retodon8

[quote]Quote:[hr]Still... It's pointless.[hr][/quote]
But you are talking about the main subject of this thread.

So using transitive thinking...

Thread is the topic.
The topic is pointless.

Tread -> Topic -> Pointless.

Thread = pointless.

But seriously Glowy Box... if your arguments have degenerated to: "Still... It's pointless."... That's like a little kid shouting, "But your still DUMB!" It's... not a very good viewpoint and makes people laugh at you when you are trying to have a serious debate.-----------------------
[url=http://Galaxie.Spatang.com][img]http://i34.photobucket.com/albums/d134/Galaxieretter/New-blegd-smeeg-banner-60.png[/img][/url]

title: Re: ...
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]
But you are talking about the main subject of this thread.

So using transitive thinking...

Thread is the topic.
The topic is pointless.

Tread -> Topic -> Pointless.

Thread = pointless.

But seriously Glowy Box... if your arguments have degenerated to: "Still... It's pointless."... That's like a little kid shouting, "But your still DUMB!" It's... not a very good viewpoint and makes people laugh at you when you are trying to have a serious debate.
[hr][/quote]

That was wholly laughable. First of all, it was a strawman fallacy:

"Still... It's pointless" == "But your still DUMB"

The latter was an ad hominem fallacy. The former merely stated "It is pointless to do [action A], therefore it would be intelligent to stop doing [action A]". The former was logical; the latter employed a logical fallacy. Quite clearly:

"Still... It's pointless" =/= "But your still DUMB"

It was a a misrepresentation of my argument (Even though it wasn't really a debate, LMAO); ergo, it is a strawman.


j00 g0t wtfpwn3d!!!!11


Seriously though, Gal, attacking someone's debating style by the use of a strawman fallacy then saying they've degenerated is, in and of itself, poor debating skills.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...

title: Re: ...
content:
I personally still prefer buying an actual CD (or DVD) over a download.
It just feels more... "real" somehow.
Perhaps it's just that I'm old enough to have been brought up with some old-fashioned ideas.
Sofware is basically something virtual, something that doesn't really exist, depending on your definition of course, and with a CD at least it feels like I have proof that I own whatever is on it.
Like I said, old-fashioned, and I'm young enough to get used to the whole virtual ownership a bit more.

I just hope technology, and more importantly the companies selling their stuff, are able to keep up with whatever people bought from them.
I'd like to retain the rights to any software I download, even after a few decades when the company doesn't sell the software anymore.
I can imagine they don't want to keep track of all their old stuff for ages, but if I can't re-download something I already own after I deleted it, I'd feel angry about that.

These days cool paper manuals you can read through at any time are substituted for PDFs, so buying a box/case basically means just the case, the box art, and the CD, so it doesn't really matter that much anymore.
Then again I think special editions with shirts/caps/keychains/concept art/buttons/action figures/pizas/whatever are more popular than in the 1990s for instance, so who knows!Retodon8
Sheep happens! [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Keen/Graphics/K1_nme_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: Re: ...
content:
I'm with you on this, Ret. I love original boxed games, and still actively seek old games in their original packaging. I used to read manuals all the time back in the DOS days, but now you don't get as much to read. Although, I have noticed some games are starting to include more interesting stuff than just some cardboard and a CD. Problem is, a lot of them I'm not interested is... games have been fairly dismal for half a decade (excluding strategy/sim games, which are, in general, retaining a high level of both quality and quantity).

Anyway... my point is, if I can't get a hard copy of something I'll get a pirated one. I'm not sure if that point is relevant to this discussion, but I've typed it now and I don't feel like backtracking.

title: Re: Why?
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]There never were any sequels to Bio Menace. Part 2 and 3 are actually episodes, just like episodes 2 and 3 of Duke Nukem (the original) aren't real sequels, since Duke Nukem 2 was that.[hr][/quote]

I wrote that earlier in this thread, but a while after I posted that I realised it's not the case for all games.
After all, Keen 1, 2, and 3 are also episodes, but 2 and 3 are still considered sequels.
It wasn't really followed by a "2" something, the numbering just continued with 4.
Well, Dreams first, and it's not illogical to consider 6 part of the 456 trilogy from a consumer's perspective.
Most of those games (Secret Agent, Crystal Caves, etc.) never got any episodes after 3, so I'm not sure which is standard, the Duke Nukem method, or the Keen method.Retodon8
